metadata.title: Merge Data Frames in Python & R. Here is a simple cheat sheet of data… | by Yufeng | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Merge Data Frames in Python & R
metadata.description: Merging data frames is a must skill for people who deal with data. However, it’s hard to memorize the commands correctly when transferring from one coding language to another. In this post, I am…

all_paragraphs: Merging data frames is a must skill for people who deal with data. However, it’s hard to memorize the commands correctly when transferring from one coding language to another.

In this post, I am going to summarize a simple clean cheat sheet for merge functions in both Python and R, which is similar to one of my previous posts. In addition, I will include a comparison between Python and R in merging multiple data frames.

To note, I will only use Pandas in Python and basic functions in R for the purpose of comparing the command lines side by side. Some comprehensive library, ‘dplyr’ in R for example, is not considered.
I hope this post and the cheat sheet will be helpful to you when you have to work with both languages simultaneously.
We are using the true shooting percentage of Allen Iverson and Tracy McGrady as our toy datasets.
We can see there are three columns in the data frames, “Season”, “Pos”, and “TS.”, which stands for season index, position on the court, and true shooting percentage, respectively.
There are mainly four types of merging strategies, which include inner join, outer join, left join, and right join based on the common key (column) used to merge on.
“inner join” means only take the intersection of elements in the two data frames’ keys columns. We can use a Venn Diagram to represent the “inner join” as below.
Here are the codes in R and Python.
We can see from the tables above that only the seasons in which both Iverson and McGrady played are shown.
Let’s then look at the “outer join” strategy. “outer join” takes the union of the elements in the key columns of both data frames.
The code to perform the “outer join” in R and Python are listed below.
We can see that both languages fill “NA” values to the key element that the original data frame doesn’t have. This table shows the seasons in which one player played but the other didn’t.
“left join” takes only the elements in the first table’s key column regardless of those in the second table’s key column.
The codes of “left join” in R and Python are listed here.
“right join” is the opposite of “left join”.
And the codes to do the “right join” in Python and R are listed below.

These four types of merge constitute the majority of the “merge” usage. It’s important to differentiate the arguments to select the merging strategy in R and Python. The arguments used in R are “by.x” and “by.y”, but the argument is “how” in Python. To note, if “by.x” and “by.y” need the same value assignment in R, we can use a single argument “by” instead.
Sometimes, we need to merge two data frames based on multiple columns. The only thing we need to do is to pass a list of column names to the corresponding arguments.
In this example above, we are interested in the players’ stats comparison when the two players are playing at the same positions (“Pos”) in the same season (“Season”).
In another situation, we are interested in merging more than two data frames. We can definitely write a very long command to merge them one by one, but a better way can be the “reduce” function.
Say we have another data frame of Kobe Bryant’s true shooting percentage and we want to merge it together with those of Iverson and McGrady.

Here in the “Reduce” function of R, we need to define a function of merging two data frames and use it as the first parameter, and then pass a list of data frames as the second parameter of the “Reduce” function.

Here in the “reduce” function of Python, it is very similar to that in R. We need to define a function of merging two data frames via lambda. And we also need to pass a list of data frames to the “reduce” function.
Here is the clean cheat sheet for merging data frames in R and Python.
That’s it! I hope this post can be helpful to you.
Thank you for reading! If you like the article, please follow me on Medium. Here are some of my previous articles in data science:
